natural problem: It takes four painters working at the same rate $1.25$ work-days to finish a job. If only three painters are available, how many work-days will it take them to finish the job, working at the same rate? Express your answer as a mixed number.
natural solution: The number of workers will be inversely proportional to the time needed to complete the job. This means that the product $(\text{number of workers})\times(\text{days to complete job})$ will be a constant.
In this case, that constant will be: $$4\times 1.25=5$$ For three workers, the product will remain the same.
Let $D$ equal the number of days needed for three workers to complete the job. Then, \begin{align} 3\times D&=5\\ \Rightarrow\qquad D&=5/3=\boxed{1\frac{2}{3}} \text{work-days}. \end{align}

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes painters1 painters2 :: real
and work_days1 work_days2 :: real
assumes h0 : "painters1 = 4"
and h1 : "work_days1 = 1.25"
and h2 : "painters2 = 3"
and h3 : "painters1 * work_days1 = painters2 * work_days2"
shows  "work_days2 = 1 + 2 / 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 It takes four painters working at the same rate $1.25$ work-days to finish a job. If only three painters are available, how many work-days will it take them to finish the job, working at the same rate? Express your answer as a mixed number. The final Answer is 1\frac{2}{3}
 ### Proof
 The number of workers will be inversely proportional to the time needed to complete the job. This means that the product $(\text{number of workers})\times(\text{days to complete job})$ will be a constant.
 In this case, that constant will be: $$4\times 1.25=5$$ For three workers, the product will remain the same.
 Let $D$ equal the number of days needed for three workers to complete the job. Then, \begin{align} 3\times D&=5\\ \Rightarrow\qquad D&=5/3=\boxed{1\frac{2}{3}} \text{work-days}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes painters1 painters2 :: real
and work_days1 work_days2 :: real
assumes h0 : "painters1 = 4"
and h1 : "work_days1 = 1.25"
and h2 : "painters2 = 3"
and h3 : "painters1 * work_days1 = painters2 * work_days2"
shows  "work_days2 = 1 + 2 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Four painters can complete a job in 1.25 days. If three painters are working on the same job, how many days will it take them to finish? The final answer is $1 + \frac{2}{3}$ days.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes painters1 painters2 work_days1 work_days2 :: real
assumes h0 : "painters1 * work_days1 = painters2 * work_days2"
and h1 : "painters1 = 4"
and h2 : "work_days1 = 1.25"
and h3 : "painters2 = 3"
shows  "work_days2 = 1 + 2/3"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 It takes four painters working at the same rate $1.25$ work-days to finish a job. If only three painters are available, how many work-days will it take them to finish the job, working at the same rate? Express your answer as a mixed number. The final Answer is 1\frac{2}{3}
 ### Proof
 The number of workers will be inversely proportional to the time needed to complete the job. This means that the product $(\text{number of workers})\times(\text{days to complete job})$ will be a constant.
 In this case, that constant will be: $$4\times 1.25=5$$ For three workers, the product will remain the same.
 Let $D$ equal the number of days needed for three workers to complete the job. Then, \begin{align} 3\times D&=5\\ \Rightarrow\qquad D&=5/3=\boxed{1\frac{2}{3}} \text{work-days}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes painters1 painters2 work_days1 work_days2 :: real
assumes h0 : "painters1 * work_days1 = painters2 * work_days2"
and h1 : "painters1 = 4"
and h2 : "work_days1 = 1.25"
and h3 : "painters2 = 3"
shows  "work_days2 = 1 + 2/3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Four painters can complete a job in 1.25 days. If instead three painters were to do the job, how many days would they need to finish it? The final answer is 1 and 2/3 days.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes painters1 painters2 workdays1 workdays2 :: real
assumes h0 : "painters1 * workdays1 = 1.25"
and h1 : "painters2 = painters1 - 1"
and h2 : "painters2 * workdays2 = 1.25"
shows  "workdays2 = 1 + 2/3"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 It takes four painters working at the same rate $1.25$ work-days to finish a job. If only three painters are available, how many work-days will it take them to finish the job, working at the same rate? Express your answer as a mixed number. The final Answer is 1\frac{2}{3}
 ### Proof
 The number of workers will be inversely proportional to the time needed to complete the job. This means that the product $(\text{number of workers})\times(\text{days to complete job})$ will be a constant.
 In this case, that constant will be: $$4\times 1.25=5$$ For three workers, the product will remain the same.
 Let $D$ equal the number of days needed for three workers to complete the job. Then, \begin{align} 3\times D&=5\\ \Rightarrow\qquad D&=5/3=\boxed{1\frac{2}{3}} \text{work-days}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes painters1 painters2 workdays1 workdays2 :: real
assumes h0 : "painters1 * workdays1 = 1.25"
and h1 : "painters2 = painters1 - 1"
and h2 : "painters2 * workdays2 = 1.25"
shows  "workdays2 = 1 + 2/3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: If a group of painters can paint a house in a certain number of days and they do 1.25 units of work per day, then if one painter is removed from the group, and the group still does 1.25 units of work per day, how many days will it take to paint the house? The final answer is 1 and 2/3 days.

assumes h0 : "painters_1 * work_days_1 = 1.25"
and h1 : "painters_1 = 4"
and h2 : "work_days_1 = 1"
and h3 : "painters_2 = 3"
shows  "work_days_2 = 1 + 2 / 3"

 ### Proof
 The number of workers will be inversely proportional to the time needed to complete the job. This means that the product $(\text{number of workers})\times(\text{days to complete job})$ will be a constant.
 In this case, that constant will be: $$4\times 1.25=5$$ For three workers, the product will remain the same.

 ### Proof

fixes painters_one painters_two :: real

assumes h0 : "painters_one = 4"

fixes painters1 painters2 :: real
and time1 time2 :: real
assumes h0 : "painters1 = 4"
and h1 : "time1 = 1.25"
and h2 : "painters2 = 3"
and h3 : "painters1 * time1 = painters2 * time2"
shows  "time2 = 1 + 2 / 3"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 It takes four painters working at the same rate $1.25$ work-days to finish a job. If only three painters are available, how many work-days will it take them to finish the job, working at the same rate? Express your answer as a mixed number. The final Answer is 1\frac{2}{3}
 ### Proof
 The number of workers will be inversely proportional to the time needed to complete the job. This means that the product $(\text{number of workers})\times(\text{days to complete job})$ will be a constant.
 In this case, that constant will be: $$4\times 1.25=5$$ For three workers, the product will remain the same.
 Let $D$ equal the number of days needed for three workers to complete the job. Then, \begin{align} 3\times D&=5\\ \Rightarrow\qquad D&=5/3=\boxed{1\frac{2}{3}} \text{work-days}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes painters1 painters2 :: real
and time1 time2 :: real
assumes h0 : "painters1 = 4"
and h1 : "time1 = 1.25"
and h2 : "painters2 = 3"
and h3 : "painters1 * time1 = painters2 * time2"
shows  "time2 = 1 + 2 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: If 4 painters can paint a house in 1.25 hours, how long would it take for 3 painters to paint the same house, assuming they all work at the same rate? The final answer is 1 hour and 40 minutes or 1 hour and 2/3 of an hour.

 ### Proof

 In this case, that constant will be: $$4\times 1.25=5$$ For three workers, the product will remain the same.

fixes painters1 painters2 work_days1 work_days2 :: real
assumes h0 : "painters1 = 4"

and h3 : "painters1 * work_days1 = painters2 * work_days2"
shows  "work_days2 = 1 + 2 / 3"

a_7.informal problem: Four painters can complete a job in 1.25 days. If only three painters are working on the same job, how many days will it take for them to complete it? The final answer is 1 and 2/3 days.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes painters1 painters2 :: real
and workdays1 workdays2 :: real
assumes h0 : "painters1 * workdays1 = 5"
and h1 : "painters2 * workdays2 = 5"
and h2 : "painters1 = 4"
and h3 : "painters2 = 3"
shows  "workdays2 = 1 + 2 / 3"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 It takes four painters working at the same rate $1.25$ work-days to finish a job. If only three painters are available, how many work-days will it take them to finish the job, working at the same rate? Express your answer as a mixed number. The final Answer is 1\frac{2}{3}
 ### Proof
 The number of workers will be inversely proportional to the time needed to complete the job. This means that the product $(\text{number of workers})\times(\text{days to complete job})$ will be a constant.
 In this case, that constant will be: $$4\times 1.25=5$$ For three workers, the product will remain the same.
 Let $D$ equal the number of days needed for three workers to complete the job. Then, \begin{align} 3\times D&=5\\ \Rightarrow\qquad D&=5/3=\boxed{1\frac{2}{3}} \text{work-days}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes painters1 painters2 :: real
and workdays1 workdays2 :: real
assumes h0 : "painters1 * workdays1 = 5"
and h1 : "painters2 * workdays2 = 5"
and h2 : "painters1 = 4"
and h3 : "painters2 = 3"
shows  "workdays2 = 1 + 2 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: If 4 painters can complete a painting job in a certain number of days, and 3 painters can complete the same job in a different number of days, find the number of days it takes for the 3 painters to complete the job, given that the product of the number of painters and the number of days is the same for both groups (5). The final answer is $\frac{5}{3}$, or $1 + \frac{2}{3}$ days.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_painters1 num_painters2 :: real
and work_days1 work_days2 :: real
assumes h0 : "num_painters1 * work_days1 = num_painters2 * work_days2"
and h1 : "num_painters1 = 4"
and h2 : "work_days1 = 1.25"
and h3 : "num_painters2 = 3"
shows  "work_days2 = 1 + 2 / 3"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 It takes four painters working at the same rate $1.25$ work-days to finish a job. If only three painters are available, how many work-days will it take them to finish the job, working at the same rate? Express your answer as a mixed number. The final Answer is 1\frac{2}{3}

 *)

theorem
fixes num_painters1 num_painters2 :: real
and work_days1 work_days2 :: real
assumes h0 : "num_painters1 * work_days1 = num_painters2 * work_days2"
and h1 : "num_painters1 = 4"
and h2 : "work_days1 = 1.25"
and h3 : "num_painters2 = 3"
shows  "work_days2 = 1 + 2 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: If 4 painters can finish a painting job in 1.25 days, how many days will it take for 3 painters to finish the same job? The final answer is 1 and 2/3 days.
